http://news.yahoo.com/poll-sees-ruling-akp-winning-large-majority-turkish-125944846--business.html "Turkey's ruling AK Party has increased its support by six percentage points ahead of a snap election on Sunday, pollster Adil Gur said on Thursday, enough to form a single-party majority after falling short in a June poll. "The forecast by Gur's A&G Research puts AKP votes at 47.2 percent, well above those reported by other recent polls, which generally show the party slightly increasing its share but still unable to win enough votes to form a government on its own. "In a separate poll released on Thursday, MetroPoll found that the AKP would still fail to secure a majority, winning 43.3 percent of the vote . . . .
. . . 
"While everyone is expecting a coalition, our result was a surprise. Respondents said they want a single-party government for stability and the economy," Gur told Reuters. "It will not be a borderline majority. Between 285 and 290 (AKP) lawmakers are to win" in the 550-seat parliament.  "After the June 7 election, voters do not see a possibility of a coalition with the AKP." "A&G conducted its poll of 4,536 people on Oct. 24-25. The centre-left Republican People's Party (CHP) is seen winning 25.3 percent, compared with 24.9 percent in the last vote. "The Nationalist Movement Party (MHP) is expected to lose the most number of votes, falling to 13.5 percent from 16.2 percent, according to A&G. The pro-Kurdish Peoples' Democratic Party (HDP) is forecast to take 12.2 percent, compared with 13.1 percent in June, but will win more seats than the MHP, Gur said. "For its part, MetroPoll forecast CHP at 25.9 percent, MHP at 14.8 percent and the HDP at 13.4 percent in the Sunday election.

COMMENT:   Kostyafish made 2 good points Oct 29, 2015 05:08AM about things that could dramatically change the results:  HDP not attaining the 10% threshold and the power AKP has to manipulate the results.   Forecasting 100% is risky, and don't think this question merits such a strong forecast for a plurality.

The Turkish parliament consists of 550 seats. The number of seats needed for a majority government is 278 (¬50.5%) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey#Parliamentary_groups). The threshold for the elections stands on 10%.   The latest elections in June 2015 resulted in hung government and in a failure to form a coalition. There are four parties that passed the threshold in June 2015 (http://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2015/oct/28/turkey-election-2015-guide-parties-polls-electoral-system):  *AKP - The ruling conservative party of the current  president of Turkey Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, won 258 seats 
*CHP - Social democrats, won 131 seats 
*HDP - Kurdish liberal party that effectively gathers the votes of the opposition, won 80 seats
*MHP - Turkish nationalists, won 79 seats According to most of the polls, the upcoming elections' results will be approximately the same as in June. The possible wildcard for these elections is the danger of falsifications that are expected to be implemented by the ruling party (AKP), and which may result in stealing the necessary 20 seats from the other parties; or in HDP (the main opposition party) not passing the threshold (which will boost the other parties greatly and give AKP the coveted majority).  Will give most of the probability to the plurality government however will leave some chance to a majority government. Not forming a government (non plurality) is not an option, as Turkey is highly unlikely to go to elections third time in one year.

COMMENT:  All along it has not looked favorable for AKP to gain a majority.  I have imagined 2 positive scenarios for AKP:  1) disenfranchisement of voters in Kurdish areas, and 2) citizen fatigue with the chaos that has resulted from not having a fully functioning government. . . a "let's just get this over with and give AKP what it wants so we can move on!" attitude.
I don't see either of those scenarios developing now, or in the next few days.

AKP narrows campaign focus as polls show little chance of single rule In a bid to heighten its chances of forming a single-party government, the Justice and Development Party (AKP) has narrowed its campaign focus to 40 provinces where it hopes to increase its seat totals in the last week before the Nov. 1 snap election. “The goal is not increasing the percentage of votes, but to increase the number of seats,” said Mustafa Ataş, the AKP’s executive in charge of the party’s organization.  As the AKP does not see a chance to form a single-party government according to recent surveys, the party will push for specific provinces. “If necessary we’ll transport those who want to vote but [are] outside of their provinces at that moment,” Ataş stated. The party held its last election strategy meeting on Oct. 22. During the meeting the party discussed all the surveys which have been conducted since the Oct. 10 Ankara bombing. The surveys indicated there was no chance for an AKP single-party government, though there was an increasing trend.  Therefore, the party decided to increase their campaign push in 40 provinces where the AKP lost or won by a small number of votes in the June 7 elections. “We are working on which groups are not voting for the AKP and what their complaints are,” Ataş said, adding they would work to convince those did not go to the polls previously to do so this time. The AKP faces a tough challenge to be able to form a single-party government in the upcoming Nov. 1 snap election, former Energy Minister Taner Yıldız has acknowledged. “This is our goal. Current surveys show that we are very close to this but we are not there yet. They show that we are right on the border,” Yıldız told journalists on Oct. 22, stressing the importance of the last 10 days of campaigning before Nov. 1.  “We need to achieve our goal of ruling on our own, not only for the AK Parti [AKP], but also to be able to maintain Turkey’s stability and ensure its normalization. I hope we will achieve it, even if only with a critical number [of seats],” he said, adding that the party was at “the critical threshold.” Babacan, N. (2015, October 27). AKP narrows campaign focus as polls show little chance of single rule. Hürriyet Daily News [Ankara]. I'm shifting probabilities a little more towards a majority. The reason AKP didn't get a majority last time was because the HDP got more than 10% of the vote share and hence entered parliament. Polls till now indicate that the HDP is likely to retain its vote share this time. Thus, AKP's main hope is to take votes from the other parties, in particular the nationalist MHP. The hard line taken against terrorism may be helping them here. A combination of attracting MHP voters plus making it difficult for HDP supporters to turn out could come close to giving AKP the 18 additional seats needed for a majority. However, what has swayed me the most is Angela Merkel's indication that the EU is considering giving Turks (among other things) visa-free entry, in return for Turkey keeping Syrian refugees (Turkey is currently the only applicant to the EU which does not have this concession).  The AKP is bargaining hard at the moment, and this may attract some of the more liberal/secular voters as well, who have seen Turkey repeatedly rebuffed by Europe in the past. http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/merkels-visit-strikes-cynical-chord-in-turks.aspx?pageID=238&nID=90078&NewsCatID=416 http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/0d4495d4-7416-11e5-bdb1-e6e4767162cc.html?ftcamp=crm/email/20151019/nbe/InTodaysFT/product#axzz3p5rNxjM2

In a September 12th forecast, I wrote that his assets that would change his polling trend were:
He could win by declaring he is the war president and wrap the flag around him. 
He could employ other means to convince and coerce non-supportive party opposition to support him that went to the MHP. His "tough talk appears" to have regained nationalists who were supporting the MHP, including bruising rhetorical attacks on the West, and the government’s counter-terror operations against separatist Kurds (Dettmer, 2015). With just 12 days to go to the November 1 polls, Erdoğan and top party officials have intensified their belligerent rhetoric, lambasting Europeans and the West in general and maintaining an 'us-verses-them' view of the country. The Kurds, members of other minority communities, leftists and opposition activists are being relegated to 'them' status in a politics of polarization which will make it highly difficult to agree on a coalition government after the November 1 polls, if the AKP fails to secure a majority (ibid). In general, he has returned to the rhetoric that allowed him to stay in power, He is angry that the US is supporting groups in Syria that he opposes and that the US will not permit a no-fly zone in Syria that will extend his influence. But he is framing it as an insult against Turkey and returns to an us against them strategy that has all but alienated his neighbors but not so much his voters. But his neighboring countries do not vote in the election.  He may gain votes from the National Action Party, but perhaps not enough to make the swap vote into a majority, that depends on how many voters he gathers from the MHP.  The opposition parties do not have adequate resources to finance a new campaign. Almost all opposition channels are banned from major cable TV operators as well as broadcasting platforms (Kiniklioğlu, 2015). This is a complaint other media have reported as well. Opposition newspapers have been sacked and Turkey ranks  #154 out of 180 by Reporters without Borders in Journalism freedom. https://index.rsf.org/#!/index-details/TUR
This gives the AKP more media coverage than the opposition groups in this election in Turkey. Source: According to data Al-Monitor acquired from open news sources, the balance sheet of the violence between July 20 and Sept. 13 shows: In this eight-week period, fatalities among Turkish security forces (soldiers, police and village guards) total 113. Of those, 62 (55%) were caused by improvised explosive devices (IEDs), which points to IEDs as the basic weapon of upcoming clashes. Another 21 security officials (19%) were killed in execution-style attacks. Since 74% of the fatalities were caused by IED and execution-style attacks, it is likely that the PKK has decided to use indirect attacks instead of directly clashing with Turkish security forces.
Also, 92 civilians were killed in the clashes. It is not clear who was behind 41 (45%) of those deaths; because of continuing violence, full investigations cannot be conducted. There were 75 civilian deaths (82%) in cities and towns, indicating an increase in civilian deaths as clashes shift to urban areas. Another significant figure: About 30% of the civilians killed were women.
Open news sources don’t offer reliable information on PKK casualties. The only number available was "1,116 PKK killed," reported by Turkey’s official Anatolian News Agency without quoting a source.​ However, security sources Al-Monitor consulted in Ankara say the PKK is likely to have sustained 250-300 fatalities, with about 70% of them in air attacks.

Source: Dateline 9-13-15 Since Sept. 8, Turkey has been the scene of nationwide attacks on Kurds that are unprecedented since the PKK took up arms in 1984. The wave of violence erupted after two massive PKK bomb attacks killed 16 soldiers and 14 policemen on Sept. 6 and Sept. 8, respectively, spreading to almost all the provinces outside the Kurdish-majority regions of the southeast. Nationalist groups took to the streets, assaulting Kurdish civilians, Kurdish-owned businesses and offices of the pro-Kurdish Peoples’ Democratic Party (HDP), which had emerged as Turkey’s third-largest party in the June 7 elections, winning 13.1% of the vote and 80 seats in the 550-member parliament. The party’s offices in 56 provinces and districts were stoned, vandalized and torched. The attacks reached a peak late Sept. 8 when a mob of some 500 people stormed HDP headquarters in downtown Ankara, ransacking and burning part of the building. Turkish nationalists, reported to have mobilized via social media, also attacked intercity buses carrying passengers to Kurdish-majority regions. Dozens of buses, singled out according to their license plates or company names, had their windows broken under hails of stones, while others were stopped and their passengers verbally and physically harassed. As a result, bus companies operating between the western regions and Diyarbakir, the largest city in the southeast, canceled services Sept. 9-10 to protest the violence. Impoverished Kurdish workers struggling to make a living from seasonal agricultural jobs across the country were not spared beatings and harassment. Meanwhile, one of the worst nights of horror unfolded Sept. 8 in the central Anatolian city of Kirsehir, where more than 20 Kurdish-owned businesses and shops, including the city’s only bookstore, were torched. The local HDP office was vandalized, and vehicles bound for the southeast were stoned at the city’s bus terminal. According to witnesses, the assailants, who numbered in the thousands, carried lists of their targets. Kirsehir Gov. Necati Senturk blamed the violence on “provocateurs who mingled into an innocent demonstration to condemn terrorism.”

"Both parties' voter profile is close to each other, and according to our research, the AK Party grassroots want to see the MHP as a coalition partner and vice versa. But, Bahçeli's stance toward the coalition talks created a disturbance among the voters, and it will probably result in a loss in the MHP's votes," he added.  According to the survey, the AK Party would be able to come to power alone by receiving 43.9 percent of the vote in the Nov. 1 elections with a 3 percent increase in its votes, while the CHP followed it with 26.2 percent with a 1.2 percent increase in its votes. The MHP appears to decrease to 14.1 percent from 16.3 percent while the HDP would decrease to 12.3 percent from 13.1 percent.

Ergodan would like a two thirds majority to make constitutional changes to the power of the presidency. Currently, as a result of the June parliamentary elections, he has less than 1/2 of the seats (258 of 550), even preventing the formation of a majority government. What are the possibilities?
---Less than a plurality: CHP with 132 seats (25.1% of the June vote) would need to overtake the AKP (258 seats, 40.7%)
---Plurality: Maintain a lead over CHP
---Majority: Requires a gain of 18 AKP seats over the June election result.  I see two obvious way that this could happen: 1) Parties are required to obtain 10% of the vote for representation in parliament. The Kurdish (HDP) party earned 13% of the vote and 80 seats in the June election, preventing an AKP majority. One strategy would be to prevent HDP from obtaining the 10% result in the November vote, freeing 80 seats, pushing AKP past the majority total.  Several sources indicate the campaign against the PKK, may be an attempt to split the Kurdish HDP vote. 2) Increasing the turn out in non Kurdish areas to a level where the HDP vote is less than 10%. I'll give Ergodan a 60% chance of keeping the HDP vote under 10%, in order to regain a majority.
